name: Tailored Cognitive Game Sessions
description: ALFRED provides personalized, low-challenge cognitive games tailored to Olivia’s preferences and privacy concerns, encouraging mental stimulation without overwhelming her. The system respects her desire for formal communication and limited notifications while supporting engagement and recovery.
scenario:
Olivia, a retired social worker, sat quietly in her living room, hesitant to engage with ALFRED despite knowing it was designed to help her cognitive recovery. She was wary of technology, especially anything that might share her data or overwhelm her with notifications. When ALFRED suggested a new cognitive game session, Olivia immediately dismissed the notification. She preferred to activate ALFRED herself, using the push-to-talk feature, and insisted on formal, sparse communication. She disliked the casual tone ALFRED sometimes used when proposing activities, finding it inappropriate and unsettling.

Meanwhile, Elena Rivera, a tech-curious user of the same system but living in a different city, eagerly embraced ALFRED’s interactive games. She relished the challenging simulations and welcomed every notification, seeing them as motivation to stay active and socially connected. Elena often discussed her progress with friends through ALFRED’s social features, enjoying the informal and lively conversations the system encouraged. Her openness to share personal data and use wearables stood in stark contrast to Olivia’s guarded approach.

Back with Olivia, she carefully customized ALFRED’s settings to block all app installations and refused any data sharing—even with her own doctor. When ALFRED suggested a slightly more demanding memory exercise, Olivia dismissed it outright, feeling it was too challenging and intrusive. She preferred the system to keep interactions minimal and formal, even when ALFRED gently reminded her to engage in mental stimulation. Despite ALFRED’s design to support her, Olivia often felt isolated and frustrated by the rigid boundaries she placed on the technology.

Elena, on the other hand, found ALFRED’s constant encouragement invigorating. She accepted video check-ins with her caregiver and enjoyed learning new features from ALFRED’s detailed explanations. Her willingness to adapt and share data allowed the system to tailor experiences dynamically, enhancing her engagement and physical activity. The difference was clear: where Elena viewed ALFRED as a partner in an active lifestyle, Olivia saw it as a cautious aid, one to be controlled tightly to protect her privacy and peace of mind. This divergence highlighted the delicate balance ALFRED must maintain to serve older adults with vastly differing needs and attitudes toward technology.
